raw_text:
Howl helps boost Japan's cinemas
 
 Japan's box office received a 3.8% boost last year, with ticket sales worth 211bn yen (£1.08bn).
 
 The surge was led by animated movie Howl's Moving Castle, which took 20bn yen (£102m) to become the biggest film in Japan in 2004. It is expected to match the 30.7bn yen (£157m) record of Hayao Miyazaki's previous film Spirited Away. Japan Motion Picture Producers figures showed that 170 million cinema admissions were made in Japan in 2004. The Last Samurai, starring Tom Cruise, was the biggest foreign movie hit in Japan last year, taking 13.8bn yen (£70.7m).
 
 It was followed by Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, Finding Nemo and The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King. The second highest-grossing Japanese film was romantic drama Crying Out Love in the Centre of the World, followed by Be With You and Pocket Monsters Advanced Generation. Japanese films accounted for 37.5% of Japan's box office total last year, with foreign films taking the remaining 62.5%. This represented a 4.5% gain for the proportion of Japanese films in 2004 compared to 2003. The number of Japanese films released rose to 310 in 2004 from 287 the previous year. Sales of movies on DVD and video amounted to 497bn yen (£2.54bn) for the year.

Animated film Howl's Moving Castle led the surge, followed by The Last Samurai and Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban. Japanese films accounted for 37.5% of total box office revenue, up from 32.1% in 2003.

Japanese films made up 37.5% of total box office revenue, and sales of DVDs and videos reached 497 billion yen (£2.54 billion).

opencoder:1.5b:
Howl helps boost Japan's cinemas by introducing a new animated movie, Howl's Moving Castle. The rise was attributed to this movie which increased the box office sales of Japan from 20 billion yen to become the biggest film in Japan in 2004. It is expected to match the record set at 30.7 billion yen for Hayao Miyazaki's previous movie Spirited Away.

Japan's film production figures have confirmed that approximately 170 million cinema admissions were made in Japan for 2004 as compared to 2003, signalling a significant expansion in cinema sales.

The film was one of the highest grossing films in Japan last year and was followed by Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, Finding Nemo and The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King, and Be With You and Pocket Monsters. The movie Crying Out Love in the Centre of the World came second with a high sales figure and followed closely by other romantic drama films.

Japan's film revenues rose from 287 to 310 movies as part of a larger increase in cinema sales in 2004 compared to 2003. Sales of movies on DVD and video accounted for approximately $497 billion yen, reflecting the film merchandise exports.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary should preserve key ideas and details, including:

1. The boost in Japan's cinemas was led by animated movie Howl's Moving Castle.
2. The biggest film in 2004 was Spirited Away, which took 20bn yen (£157m) to become the biggest film in Japan in 2004.
3. Japan Motion Picture Producers figures showed that 170 million cinema admissions were made in Japan last year.
4. The second highest-grossing Japanese film was romantic drama Crying Out Love in the Centre of the World, followed by Finding Nemo and The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King.
5. Foreign films accounted for 37.5% of Japan's box office total last year, with foreign films taking the remaining 62.5%.
6. Japanese films accounted for 310 in 2004 compared to 287 in 2003.
7. Sales of movies on DVD and video amounted to 497bn yen (£2.54bn) for the year.

Japan's box office saw a significant boost last year, rising by 3.8% overall, with Howl's Moving Castle leading the charge. The total revenue increased from 211 billion yen to 215.7 billion yen due to this movie becoming Japan's biggest film in 2004 and expected to match Hayao Miyazaki's spiralited away. Other hits like Last Samurai and Finding Nemo followed closely, while foreign films accounted for the remaining 62.5%. Japanese films now made up 37.5% of the total, an increase from 34% last year, with a rise in DVD/Video sales by 11% compared to the previous year.
tinyllama:1.1b: Japan saw a 3.8% increase in box office revenue, with animated movie "Howl's Moving Castle" contributing significantly to this boost. The title took 20 billion yen (£1.08bn) to become the biggest Japanese film of 2004, with the previous record set by Hayao Miyazaki's "Spirited Away". Japanese cinema admissions reached a total of 170 million in 2004, with 13.8 billion yen (£70.7m) coming from foreign movies. The second highest-grossing film of the year was romantic drama "Crying Out Love in the Centre of the World", followed by animated epic "Be With You" and "Pocket Monsters Advanced Generation". Japanese films accounted for 37.5% of Japan's box office total, with foreign films making up the remaining 62.5%. The number of Japanese films released rose to 310 in 2004 from 287 the previous year, while sales of movies on DVD and video amounted to 497 billion yen (£2.54bn) for the year.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In 2004, Howl's Moving Castle, a fantasy-adventure movie starring Bryan Cranston and Scarlett Johansson, became the biggest film in Japan with 20 billion yen (£102 million). Its sequel, The Last Samurai, was the biggest foreign hit, taking 13.8 billion yen (£70.7 million). Japanese movies, including romantic drama Crying Out Love in the Centre of the World and Be With You, accounted for 37.5% of Japan's box office revenue in 2004, with foreign films taking the remaining 62.5%. This represented a significant increase for Japanese movies in comparison to 2003, when they made up just 3.8% of Japan's box office total. The number of Japanese films released rose to 310 in 2004 from 287 the previous year, with the growth driven by increased sales of movies on DVD and video. In terms of revenue, this represented a 4.5% increase compared to 2003.
